natural problem: A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.

However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sum die1 {1..19} = 1"
and h1 : "die1 0 = 1 / 20"
and h2 : "sum die2 ({1..8} \<union> {10..20}) = 1"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "\<forall>n. (n \<in> {1..19} \<longrightarrow> die1 n = 1 / 20) \<and> (n \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<longrightarrow> die2 n = 1 / 20)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. die1 n * die2 (24 - n)) {1..18} = 3 / 80"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sum die1 {1..19} = 1"
and h1 : "die1 0 = 1 / 20"
and h2 : "sum die2 ({1..8} \<union> {10..20}) = 1"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "\<forall>n. (n \<in> {1..19} \<longrightarrow> die1 n = 1 / 20) \<and> (n \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<longrightarrow> die2 n = 1 / 20)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. die1 n * die2 (24 - n)) {1..18} = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, with the first die having 20 faces and the second die having 20 faces. The first die has equal probability of rolling each of the numbers from 1 to 19, and a 1/20 probability of rolling a 0. The second die has equal probability of rolling each of the numbers from 1 to 8 and 10 to 20, and a 1/20 probability of rolling a 0. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on the two dice is 24? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat set"
and blank_face :: nat
and faces1 faces2 :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "faces1 = [1..<20]"
and h3 : "faces2 = [1..<9] @ [10..<21]"
and h4 : "blank_face = 0"
and h5 : "die1 = set (blank_face # faces1)"
and h6 : "die2 = set (blank_face # faces2)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (x,y). x + y = 24) (set (List.product faces1 faces2)) = 3 / 80"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat set"
and blank_face :: nat
and faces1 faces2 :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "faces1 = [1..<20]"
and h3 : "faces2 = [1..<9] @ [10..<21]"
and h4 : "blank_face = 0"
and h5 : "die1 = set (blank_face # faces1)"
and h6 : "die2 = set (blank_face # faces2)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> (x,y). x + y = 24) (set (List.product faces1 faces2)) = 3 / 80"

a_1.informal problem: Two 20-sided dice are rolled, where the faces of the first die are numbered from 1 to 19 and the faces of the second die are numbered from 1 to 8 and from 10 to 20. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled is 24? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat set"
and p24 :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> die1 \<and> (\<exists>y \<in> die2. x + y = 24)} = 3"
and h3 : "p24 = (real (card {x. x \<in> die1 \<and> (\<exists>y \<in> die2. x + y = 24)}) / (real (card die1 * card die2)))"
shows  "p24 = 3 / 80"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat set"
and p24 :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> die1 \<and> (\<exists>y \<in> die2. x + y = 24)} = 3"
and h3 : "p24 = (real (card {x. x \<in> die1 \<and> (\<exists>y \<in> die2. x + y = 24)}) / (real (card die1 * card die2)))"
shows  "p24 = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are two 20-sided dice, die1 and die2. If you roll both dice, what is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled is exactly 24? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>n\<in>{1..19}. die1 n) = 19 / 20"
and h1 : "die1 0 = 1 / 20"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>n\<in>{1..8}\<union>{10..20}. die2 n) = 19 / 20"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "(\<forall>n\<in>{1..19}. die1 n = 1 / 20)"
and h5 : "(\<forall>n\<in>{1..8}\<union>{10..20}. die2 n = 1 / 20)"
shows  "(\<Sum>n\<in>{1..19}. die1 n * die2 (24 - n)) = 3 / 80"

 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>n\<in>{1..19}. die1 n) = 19 / 20"

a_3.informal problem: Suppose there are two 20-sided dice. The first die has a probability of $\frac{1}{20}$ of rolling each number from $1$ to $19$, and a probability of $\frac{19}{20}$ of rolling a $0$. The second die has a probability of $\frac{1}{20}$ of rolling each number from $1$ to $8$, and from $10$ to $20$, and a probability of $\frac{19}{20}$ of rolling a $0$. What is the probability of rolling the two dice such that their sum is $24$? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..19} \<longrightarrow> die1 n = 1/20"
and h1 : "die1 0 = 1/20"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<longrightarrow> die2 n = 1/20"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1/20"
and h4 : "die2 9 = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. die1 n * die2 (24 - n)) {1..20} = 3 / 80"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..19} \<longrightarrow> die1 n = 1/20"
and h1 : "die1 0 = 1/20"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<longrightarrow> die2 n = 1/20"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1/20"
and h4 : "die2 9 = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. die1 n * die2 (24 - n)) {1..20} = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

Die 2 also has 20 faces, numbered 0 to 20, but face 9 has a probability of 0, and the other faces have a probability of 1/20. What is the probability of the sum of the numbers rolled on these two dice being 24? The final answer is 3/80.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..19} \<union> {0}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<union> {0}"
and h2 : "card die1 = 20"
and h3 : "card die2 = 20"
and h4 : "prob_space die1"
and h5 : "prob_space die2"
and h6 : "independent_events die1 die2"
shows  "prob (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y = 24) die1 die2 = 3 / 80"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "die1 = {1..19} \<union> {0}"
and h1 : "die2 = {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<union> {0}"
and h2 : "card die1 = 20"
and h3 : "card die2 = 20"
and h4 : "prob_space die1"
and h5 : "prob_space die2"
and h6 : "independent_events die1 die2"
shows  "prob (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y = 24) die1 die2 = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Two dice are rolled. One die has 20 faces, with numbers from 1 to 19 and a 0. The other die has 20 faces, with numbers from 1 to 8, 10 to 20, and a 0. Given that the two dice are independent, what is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled is 24? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sum die1 {1 .. 19} = 19 / 20"
and h1 : "sum die2 {1 .. 8, 10 .. 20} = 19 / 20"
and h2 : "die1 0 = 1 / 20"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "sum (\<lambda>x. die1 x * die2 (24 - x)) {1 .. 19} = prob"
shows  "prob = 3 / 80"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sum die1 {1 .. 19} = 19 / 20"
and h1 : "sum die2 {1 .. 8, 10 .. 20} = 19 / 20"
and h2 : "die1 0 = 1 / 20"
and h3 : "die2 0 = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "sum (\<lambda>x. die1 x * die2 (24 - x)) {1 .. 19} = prob"
shows  "prob = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Two dice have different numbers of sides. The first die has 19 sides, numbered 1 to 19. The second die has 20 sides, numbered 1 to 8, 10 to 20, and 0. Each side on the first die has a probability of $\frac{19}{20}$ of being rolled, and the 0 has a probability of $\frac{1}{20}$. Similarly, each side on the second die (except for 0) has a probability of $\frac{19}{20}$ of being rolled, and the 0 has a probability of $\frac{1}{20}$. Find the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on the two dice is 24. The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1..19}"
and h1 : "finite {1..8, 10..20}"
and h2 : "card {1..19} = 19"
and h3 : "card {1..8, 10..20} = 19"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>x\<in>{1..19}. die1 x) = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..8, 10..20}. die2 x) = 1"
and h5 : "die1 0 = die2 0 = 1/20"
and h6 : "(\<forall>x y. (x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20}) \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 24) \<or> (\<exists>x y. (x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20}) \<and> x + y = 24)"
shows  " (\<Sum> (x,y) \<in> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20} \<and> x + y = 24}. die1 x * die2 y) = 3 / 80"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1..19}"
and h1 : "finite {1..8, 10..20}"
and h2 : "card {1..19} = 19"
and h3 : "card {1..8, 10..20} = 19"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>x\<in>{1..19}. die1 x) = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..8, 10..20}. die2 x) = 1"
and h5 : "die1 0 = die2 0 = 1/20"
and h6 : "(\<forall>x y. (x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20}) \<longrightarrow> x + y \<noteq> 24) \<or> (\<exists>x y. (x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20}) \<and> x + y = 24)"
shows  " (\<Sum> (x,y) \<in> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..19} \<and> y \<in> {1..8, 10..20} \<and> x + y = 24}. die1 x * die2 y) = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, one with 19 faces numbered 1 to 19, and the other with 19 faces numbered 1 to 8 and 10 to 20. The probability of rolling a 0 on both dice is 1/20. What is the probability of rolling a sum of 24 on these two dice? The final answer is 3/80.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "die1 = {1..19} \<union> {0}"
and h3 : "die2 = {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<union> {0}"
and h4 : "finite die1"
and h5 : "finite die2"
shows  "card {(x, y) \<in> die1 \<times> die2. x + y = 24} / (real (card (die1 \<times> die2))) = 3 / 80"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face.  However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "card die1 = 20"
and h1 : "card die2 = 20"
and h2 : "die1 = {1..19} \<union> {0}"
and h3 : "die2 = {1..8} \<union> {10..20} \<union> {0}"
and h4 : "finite die1"
and h5 : "finite die2"
shows  "card {(x, y) \<in> die1 \<times> die2. x + y = 24} / (real (card (die1 \<times> die2))) = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Two 20-sided dice are used in a game. The first die, die1, has numbers from 0 to 19, while the second die, die2, has numbers from 0 to 8 and 10 to 20. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on the two dice is equal to 24? The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d1 d2 :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i \<noteq> 0} = 19"
and h1 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d2 i \<noteq> 0} = 19"
and h2 : "(\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> d1 i \<in> {1..19})"
and h3 : "(\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d2 i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> d2 i \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20})"
and h4 : "P = card {(i,j). i \<in> {1..20} \<and> j \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i + d2 j = 24} / (card {1..20} * card {1..20})"
shows  "P = 3 / 80"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $19$ and has one blank face. Another fair, twenty-faced die has $19$ of its faces numbered from $1$ through $8$ and $10$ through $20$ and has one blank face. When the two dice are rolled, what is the probability that the sum of the two numbers facing up will be $24?$ Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{80}
 ### Proof
 If both dice were numbered $1$ through $20,$ we could get a sum of $24$ in the following ways: \begin{align} 4&+20\\ 5&+19\\ 6&+18\\ & \ \, \vdots \\ 18&+6\\ 19&+5\\ 20&+4 \end{align} This is a total of $20-4+1=17$ ways.
 However, the first die does not have a face with $20,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $20+4.$  Also, the second die does not have a face with $9,$ so we must remove the possibility of rolling $15+9.$ This leaves $17-2=15$ possible ways to roll $24.$ There are a total of $20\cdot 20=400$ possible rolls, so the final probability is: $$\frac{15}{400}=\boxed{\frac{3}{80}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes d1 d2 :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i \<noteq> 0} = 19"
and h1 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d2 i \<noteq> 0} = 19"
and h2 : "(\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> d1 i \<in> {1..19})"
and h3 : "(\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..20} \<and> d2 i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> d2 i \<in> {1..8} \<union> {10..20})"
and h4 : "P = card {(i,j). i \<in> {1..20} \<and> j \<in> {1..20} \<and> d1 i + d2 j = 24} / (card {1..20} * card {1..20})"
shows  "P = 3 / 80"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are two sets of distinct numbers, d1 and d2. The set d1 contains 19 non-zero numbers from 1 to 19, and the set d2 contains 19 non-zero numbers from 1 to 8 and 10 to 20. Let P be the probability that the sum of a randomly chosen number from d1 and a randomly chosen number from d2 equals 24. Find the value of P. The final answer is $\frac{3}{80}$.
